prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Venus 3.5 mm continuum and OCS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Primary target = 85 and 99 GHz continuum emission. Second target = challange to detect OCS lines

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note: This proposal contains 2 ScienceGoals (SGs) using Band-3 and 4, respectively. The 4 continuum emission images from these 2 SGs will be analyzed together to improve the sensitivity to SO2 scale height. For this purpose, we request (as an ideal situation) the observations of these 2 SGs to be performed with a temporal contiguity in the same observation day. A separation up to ~4 hrs between the execution of 2 SGs are still acceptable, but we do not prefer that 2 SGs are separated into several days. This is an essential point in order to analyze 4 continuum channels from 2 SGs without any contaminations from the temporal variation of the Venus atmosphere (which atmosphere rotates the planet within 4-5 days). In case that 2 SGs were executed with a certain long separation due to any reasons, then, we will separately analyze 2 continuum channles from each SG. This still gives an opportunity to achieve our science purposes.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The primary immediate objective is the continuum emission at 85 and 99 GHz. 85 GHz, i.e. the longest wavelength in ALMA, is selected because of the highest transparency of Venus atmosphere, which provides the capability of observing as low as 40 - 60 km of Venus atmosphere.
Second objective is to detect (or put upper limits on) OCS lines at 85.139 and 97.301 GHz. The estimated absorption depth of OCS lines are ~0.2% against the 340 K continuum, with a line width of ~2 MHz (depending on how much OCS exists in Venus upper troposphere). The selected correlator configuration (0.15 MHz-resolution, 234 MHz-width) is optimal to search for this weak and narrow spectral feature. Note that these OCS lines are rather optional targets of this proposal, and we estimate the observation time with respect to the continuum sciences (as described in the requested RMS justification section).

Because our target is the solar system object, the largest angular scale (LAS) i.e. apparent diameter of Venus disk varies during the Cycle-3 season. The most important condition comes from our scientific requirement (as described afterwards at the justification of "time-constraint" request); that is, we need to observe Venus when most of the disk is illuminated by Sun (which occurs after 2016-Jan-11 in Cycle-3). With this requirement, Venus diameter varies from 13 arcsec to 10 arcsec. We set 13 arcsec as the largest angular scale in this OT.
Requirement on the spatial resolution originates from our scientific interest: we want to observe the latitudinal distribution of SO2 scale height with a resolution of ~30 degree. To achieve this goal, we need a spatial resolution of 1.6 and 1.3 arcsec for the 13 and 10 arcsec Venus disk, respectively. In order to estimate the most severe case, we put 1.3 arcsec for the required spatial resolution in this OT.

* Required sensitivity The goal of our science is to constrain the horizontal variation of the SO2 vertical distribution inside Venus cloud layer. We expect that the local scale height of SO2 profile (i.e. the steepness of SO2 vertical gradient above 50 km) can vary from ~0.5 to 4.5 km due to differences in the local convection activity and photochemical reactions. To well understand the spatial inhomogeneity of such atmospheric states, we require the resolution of "0.1 km" in terms of SO2 scale height (steepness of the gradient).
We will constrain SO2 scale height from ALMA observation by taking the differential image between 85 and 99 GHz "continuum" emission. As shown in Fig.2 of the attached Scientific Justification, the brightness temperatures (TB) at 85 and 99 GHz differs due to differences of the SO2 absorption coefficients (~1 K for the nominal SO2 profile), and the TB difference changes its amplitude if the scale height of SO2 profile is changed. We performed the radiative transfer calculations to estimate the required observation sensitivity to distinguish "0.1 km" differences in the SO2 scale height, and got a value of 2.5 mK in brightness temperature (with a continuum 1.8 GHz-bandwidth). This requirement is used to estimate the observation time in this proposal.
We also propose a "spectral line" observation of OCS as the second objective of this proposal. Horizontal distribution of OCS (if detected) can be used as additional info for studying the convection activity in Venus upper troposphere. OCS line depth is estimated as 0.2 % of the continuum (340 K at 99 GHz = 4.51 Jy/beam for 1.3 arcsec beam). For the estimation of required RMS level of this ScienceGoal, we leave OCS out of consideration because our intent of observing OCS is just a backup of SO2 scale height observation.
* Comment about large dynamic range: In order to accurately extract such small brightness fluctiation from the very bright disk, we subtract the uniform brightness disk model visibility from the measured visibility before synthesizing the image. This procedure has been well applied to the interferometric observations of planets (for detail, see the paper by Butler and Bastian (1999), Synthesis Imaging in Radio Astronomy II). We have substantial experiences in such a data reduction with Nobeyama Millimeter Array operation.

One of our scientific goals is to observe the local time dependence (if exists) of the Venus dayside atmosphere, in particular, differences between the noon and morning (or evening) terminator. For this purpose, we request the nightside of Venus to be suppressed smaller than 20% of the Venus disk, which gives the observation geometry of the apparent local time varying from post-noon to evening (or, from morning to pre-noon) which occurs after 2016-Jan-11 in Cycle-3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Venus is entirely covered by a thick cloud layer (H2SO4 droplet) expanding at altitudes of 45-60 km. We aim to understanding the mechanism of cloud formation and how the cloud distribution varies in spatial and temporal by observing the spatial distribution of SO2 at the lower-cloud level (~45-65 km). SO2 is the source and partially sink of H2SO4 vapor, and its vertical distribution inside the cloud layer closely connects to the cloud microphysics. Recent satellite and ground-based observations have provided observational knowledge on SO2 below and above the cloud, but not inside. This proposal focus on that unrevealed altitude region of SO2: mm-wave continuum emission can sound the Venus atmosphere at 45-65 km thanks to relatively better transparency of Venus atmosphere compared to submm domain. And, SO2 has a number of weak absorption lines at mm-wavelengths, which create a broad absorption feature under the Venus atmospheric condition. We will obtain continuum emission maps of Venus using ALMA Band-3 and 4 with a high imaging fidelity. Taking the difference between different continuum wavelengths will enable us to constrain the vertical gradient of SO2 above 50 km.
